title: Donald Trump charged in investigation over his efforts to overturn 2020 election loss

mainContent.title: Trump charged in investigation over his efforts to overturn 2020 election loss
mainContent.description: Donald Trump on Tuesday was hit with criminal charges for a third time in four months â€” this time arising from efforts to overturn his 2020 U.S. election defeat â€” as he campaigns to regain the presidency next year.

typeAttributes.deck: Former U.S. president has now been criminally charged for the 3rd time in 4 months

content.deck: No consensus on whether hearings helped prosecution chances, but testimony made for memorable sound bites
content.description: They'll be back. That's what members of the House select committee investigating former U.S. president Donald Trump's effort to overturn the 2020 election promised at the conclusion of their last public hearing of the summer. We look at what legal and political analysts say were some of the most significant moments so far.

headlinemedia.deck: WASHINGTON, DC - JULY 21: Representative Liz Cheney, a Republican from Wyoming, center, speaks during a hearing of the Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the US Capitol on July 21, 2022 in Washington, DC. The bipartisan committee, which has been gathering evidence on the January 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol, is presenting its findings in a series of televised hearings. On January 6, 2021, supporters of former President Donald Trump attacked the U.S. Capitol Building during an attempt to disrupt a congressional vote to confirm the electoral college win for President Joe Biden.  (Photo by Al Drago-Pool/Getty Images)
headlinemedia.description: WASHINGTON, DC - JULY 21: Representative Liz Cheney, a Republican from Wyoming, center, speaks during a hearing of the Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the US Capitol on July 21, 2022 in Washington, DC. The bipartisan committee, which has been gathering evidence on the January 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol, is presenting its findings in a series of televised hearings. On January 6, 2021, supporters of former President Donald Trump attacked the U.S. Capitol Building during an attempt to disrupt a congressional vote to confirm the electoral college win for President Joe Biden.  (Photo by Al Drago-Pool/Getty Images)

bio.name: Kazi Stastna
bio.biography: Kazi Stastna is a senior producer with CBCNews.ca. She has worked as a features writer and copy editor with CBC's digital news team for over a decade. Prior to that, she was at the Montreal Gazette and worked as a reporter and editor in Germany and the Czech Republic.

content.deck: Former U.S. president and 2024 Republican candidate indicted twice since April, and other cases loom
content.description: Donald Trump is defiant in the face of Espionage Act charges centred on mishandling documents while ex-president. But he now faces 40 charges overall in a case set to go to trial in March 2024, as well as ongoing probes elsewhere.

headlinemedia.deck: Former U.S. President Donald Trump gestures during an event following his arraignment on classified  document charges, at Trump National Golf Club, in Bedminster, New Jersey, U.S., June 13, 2023. REUTERS/Amr Alfiky      TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

title: Poilievre fires back at Trudeau, says housing is a federal responsibility

mainContent.title: Poilievre fires back at Trudeau, says housing is a federal responsibility
mainContent.description: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre fired back at Prime Minister Justin Trudeauâ€™s assertion that housing is not a primary federal responsibility, laying the blame for the housing crisis squarely at the Liberal governmentâ€™s feet.

typeAttributes.deck: 'No wonder he wants to wash his hands of his horrendous and unprecedented record,' said Poilievre

mainVisual.title: Poilievre says Trudeau is 'failing expensively' on housing

primary.localheadline: Minimum wage couldn't get you a 1-bedroom unit years ago. It's even worse now

content.deck: High rentsÂ in major cities mean those making minimum wageÂ are at risk of becoming homeless, report suggests
content.description: A new report released Tuesday by the Canadian Centre for PolicyÂ Alternatives found that while minimum wages have risen since 2018, they haven't increased as fast as rental rates. Researchers say this not only leaves workers spending too much on rent, but ultimatelyÂ puts minimum wage workers at risk of becoming homeless.

headlinemedia.deck: Sylvana Orellana, 23, is a Toronto renter. She says she's struggling to pay rent, provide for herself and her son, and cover the rest of her daily expenses while earning minimum wage, even with support from friends and family.
headlinemedia.alt: A woman looks at the camera for a photo.
headlinemedia.description: Sylvana Orellana, 23, is a Toronto renter. She says she's struggling to pay rent, provide for herself and her son, and cover the rest of her daily expenses while earning minimum wage, even with support from friends and family.

intlinks.description: A funding stalemate between the City of Toronto and the federal government over who is responsible for sheltering the influx of asylum seekers has left many on sleeping on the streets for weeks. intlinks.description: As demand for affordable housing continues to rise in Waterloo region, local advocates say there needs to be a bigger push for more accessible, affordable units. Kitchener's Ronald Hoppe said shock turned to anger when he found out that he will be waiting years for anÂ affordable and accessible unit.

intlinks.description: "Accessibility" can be a tricky word â€” it means something different to everyone, and depends on how individuals use a space. For these Newfoundland and Labrador venues, providing access to everyone is a priority.

bio.biography: Jason Vermes is a writer and editor for CBC Radio Digital, originally from Nova Scotia and currently based in Toronto. He frequently covers topics related to the LGBTQ community and previously reported on disability and accessibility. content.deck: Collaborative Home Ownership site offers shared partnership 'matchmaking' and events, says Vancouver Realtor
content.description: Some Lower Mainland residents are turning to unorthodox methods in the battle against unaffordable housing prices, choosing, in some cases, toÂ poolÂ money with strangers in order to buy a home.Â

headlinemedia.deck: Vancouver Realtor Noam Dolgin is helping Lower Mainland residents find partners to purchase homes. Legal advocates warn these new types of partnerships are more risky than they seem.

title: Saying 'I love you' with 1.2 million sunflowers
description: Kansas farmer Lee Wilson didn't know what to get his wife Renee for their 50th wedding anniversary, until inspiration struck. She loved sunflowers, so he decided to turn 80 acres into an unending field of yellow, growing 1.2 million blooms to mark their celebratory milestone together.

title: Former CAO accused of faking cyberattack to cover theft of $500K from Manitoba municipality
description: A former chief administrative officerÂ stole more than half a million dollars from a western Manitoba municipality's bank account, and then tried to cover it up by fabricating a story about a cyberattack and altering documents, a lawsuit filed last month alleges.

title: A kayaker takes a 11,000-km solo journey to 'reverse the bad.' There was lots of stealth camping
description: A Canadian kayaker who set out on an 11,000-kilometre solo journey from Nova Scotia, down to the Gulf of Mexico and back up the Atlantic coast last year, has reached the finish line in Halifax exactly 14 months later.

typeAttributes.deck: Mark Fuhrmann, 65, started his adventure last June in N.S., paddling to down to Gulf of Mexico and back

title: External review found military's COVID-19 vaccine policy violated Charter of Rights
description: A tribunal that is part of the military grievance process has found that the Canadian Armed Forces' COVID-19 vaccine policy violated its members' Charter rights.

typeAttributes.deck: Policy resulted in 299 people being released and another 108 leaving the armed forces on their own

title: Meta ending news availability on its platforms in Canada starting today

mainContent.title: Meta permanently ending news availability on its platforms in Canada starting today
mainContent.description: Social media giant Meta says it has officially begun ending news availability on its platforms in Canada starting Tuesday.

typeAttributes.deck: Company says implementing new policy on its platforms will take a few weeks
